resources.string: New York City, often called “The Big Apple,” is a vibrant metropolis bursting with energy, culture, and history. Known for its towering skyline, iconic landmarks, and fast-paced lifestyle, NYC holds countless fascinating facts. Times Square, now a dazzling hub of lights and entertainment, was named after The New York Times in 1904. Central Park, the green heart of the city, spans a massive 843 acres—making it even larger than the country of Monaco. The Statue of Liberty, one of the city\'s most iconic symbols, was a gift from France in 1886 and arrived in the U.S. in 350 individual pieces. NYC is also home to one of the most complex and expansive subway systems in the world, with 472 stations across the five boroughs. Perhaps most impressively, more than 800 languages are spoken in the city, making it the most linguistically diverse place on Earth. Even something as everyday as tap water stands out—New York’s is famously clean and delicious, so much so that it’s credited with making the city’s bagels and pizza taste better. From its cultural diversity to its architectural wonders, New York City continues to be a symbol of ambition, freedom, and limitless possibility.
